node.title: Quarantine halved for fully vaccinated close contacts of Omicron cases in Canberra
node.alt: A wide shot of Canberra with the lake and a tree in the right hand corner.
node.description: Fully vaccinated close contacts of the Omicron variant will now only have to isolate for seven days in the ACT as interstate travel restrictions ease.
node.content:
["Fully vaccinated close contacts of Omicron cases will no longer need to quarantine for 14 days in the ACT, instead they will only have to isolate for seven days.", "ACT Health is also updating restrictions for domestic and international travellers to the ACT from 11:59pm on Wednesday.", "Except for close contacts of interstate cases, there will no longer be any restrictions on interstate travel to the ACT.", "People will no longer need to fill out a declaration or exemption form to travel to the ACT, and all remaining high-risk geographical areas will be removed.", "The three-day quarantine requirement for fully vaccinated overseas arrivals will remain, including over the Christmas and New Year period.", "This three-day quarantine period also now applies to fully vaccinated travellers who have been in\u00a0South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Eswatini and/or Malawi. Previously fully vaccinated travellers from these countries had to complete 14 days of quarantine.", "On top of the changes for close contacts of Omicron cases, ACT Health also announced changes for secondary contacts of the Omicron variant, who will no longer be required to quarantine at all if they are not symptomatic.", "Any secondary contacts currently isolating will be contacted to inform them that they can\u00a0leave quarantine from Thursday, so long as their day six test was negative.", "Testing requirements for close contacts remain the same despite the change in quarantine, with a negative test needed on days six and 13.", "
'World-leading' vaccination rates allow for easing
", "", "
ACT Health Minister Rachel Stephen-Smith says while restrictions ease, COVID-safe practices remain important.(ABC News: Ian Cutmore)
", "ACT Health Minister Rachel Stephen-Smith announced the changes, and said the quarantine lessening for fully vaccinated close contacts came with some extra conditions.", "\"While quarantine requirements are being eased for fully vaccinated close contacts of Omicron cases, given the increased risk of potential transmission of the Omicron variant and rising case numbers in neighbouring jurisdictions, ACT Health is also updating its advice for all fully vaccinated close contacts to limit their days in the community from days eight\u00a0to 14 following exposure,\" she said.", "\"Unvaccinated close contacts of Omicron and other COVID-19 variants will of course continue to be required to undertake 14 days of quarantine.\"", "ACT health authorities said that while the territory's high vaccination rate was encouraging, it was important to continue observing COVID-safe measures.", "\"However, we all have a responsibility to continue to maintain our COVID-safe behaviours, practice physical distancing and good hand hygiene, and wear masks where they are mandated.", "\"As we have seen in neighbouring jurisdictions in recent days, the situation can change quickly.\"", "More to come."]
